summary: This legal commentary by Da Rocha J. B. (SAG) outlines key pre-trial procedures under Ghana's High Court (Civil Procedure) Rules, LI 1129. It emphasizes the necessity of proper parties and a valid cause of action, explaining rules on joinder, misjoinder, and representative actions. The paper details procedural requirements including the issuance and service of writs, the role of next friends and guardians ad litem for persons under disability, and consequences of default appearance. It also covers third-party proceedings for contribution or indemnity, and the court's discretionary powers to manage cases through summons for directions, including ordering separate trials or striking out parties to prevent prejudice. The work serves as a guide to ensuring procedural correctness in civil litigation before trial.
verdict: Not applicable; this is a procedural commentary, not a case judgment.
citations: Aegis Shipping Co, Ltd v. Volta Line Ltd [1973] 1 GLR 438
Ghana Muslims Representative Council v. Salifu [1975] 2 GLR 246
rationaleHighlights: Proper joinder of parties is essential for adjudication, but misjoinder does not defeat a cause; the court may add or strike out parties.
Persons under disability (infants, mentally disordered) must sue or defend through a next friend or guardian ad litem; failure invalidates proceedings.
A cause of action requires a legal right infringed or threatened, justifying court intervention.
The court has discretion to order separate trials or require election of causes where joinder causes delay or embarrassment.
Service of writ must be personal unless substituted service is ordered; bailiffs must certify service.
